item.content:encoded:

Open thread • Replies: 26 • Updated: 2026-02-28 02:01 UTC

OP

$120,000 a year is $10,000 a month. That is ALOT of money.

Early replies (first 3)

61910225

61910236
>>61910225
I dont get it

61910240
>>61910170
Get a clearance and work for one of the intelligence agencies NGA or NGIS and make way more.

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61910246
>>61910170
>after tax, 401k contribution, HSA, insurance you'll take home roughly 7k a month
>$3500 paystub

Lol
Lmao even

61910252
>>61910246
Why would you deduct 401k and hsa

Its not like thats not your money

61910261
>>61910252
>Its not like thats not your money
Oh goy

61910263
>>61910252
401k you have a point but HSA is a retarded cope considering you can only spend it on qualifying medical expenses. if you don't get sick then you can't really touch it.

61910276
>>61910263
Everyone has health expenses, you can even use it on stuff like gym equipment and shoes. Besides its totally voluntary im pretty sure and most people just do it because taxes

61910294
>>61910276
>Everyone has health expenses,
i don't bother going to doctors. i go to the dentist every 6 months. i use mine for fluoride treatments ($33 a year) and the occasional filling.
>stuff like gym equipment and shoes.
it needs to be medically necessary, which means you need to pay dr. shekelberg to write a letter to substantiate the 'need.'

61910340
>>61910263
it is not difficult to use $4400 of medical expenses once a year, but youre supposed to just save up all your receipts and use it down the line once you've made a bunch of money, but $4400/mo shouldn't be making or breaking your investment strategy anyways unless you're poor.
>>61910294
oh you're one of those.

61910348
>>61910170
I remember when I really did think that was a lot of money 10+ years ago. I was almost willing to move to California or bumfuck West Texas to make it since I was only making $110k at the time in metro Atlanta. Look at me now!

61910350
>>61910340
>it is not difficult to use $4400 of medical expenses once a year
again, they have to be qualifying medical expenses.
>oh you're one of those.
one of what?

61910974
>>61910170
>50k for being from poland
Kurwa bros, did I miss something?

61910999
>>61910294
>it needs to be medically necessary,
you have never used one idiot, you don't need a note from any doctor, and you can use all that money to pay Medicare premiums once you retire. you will 100% use the money in a HSA and getting it pretaxed increases your actual disposable income

61911310
>>61910999
>you have never used one idiot, you don't need a note from any doctor,
i literally used my HSA card yesterday at a dentist appointment you dumb fucking nigger.
>you don't need a note from any doctor
https://www.healthequity.com/hsa-qme

61911598
>>61910252
Basically, after covering all the basics to live ok now and in the future you really don't have much "disposable" income.

$7k doesn't count rent, utilities, car insurance, car maintenance, gas, food

61911639
>>61910263
The point of a HSA is that you never spend it, it reduces your taxable income and after age 59 it’s basically a traditional 401(k).

>get 401(k) match
>max HSA
>max Roth
>go back and max 401(k) if you can

61911652
>>61911598
>make $80k
>max 401(k), HSA, Roth, and do another 10 percent to backdoor Roth
>$1,350 in total monthly expenses
>$600 to do whatever with each month
But also, I split the rent and my gf buys the groceries because she earns more. YMMV.

61913412
>>61910240
Do you have someone i can contact?

61913572
>>61910246
Hilarious pic, anon.

61913990
>>61913412
Move to DC

61914025
>>61910263
>if you don't get sick then you can't really touch it.
You can use that shit on anything. I'm wearing a pair of prescription glasses that cost around $5k that I paid for with my HSA, half of that being an employer match. You can use it to buy exercise equipment, red light panels, whatever. Basically if you ever buy anything tangentially related to health, you can pay for it with your HSA.

61914045
>>61910170
I make 120k a year.
Right off the bat, I take home maybe half of it.
Do I need to keep talking? This country is a scam.

61914081
>>61910170
It used to be. Not any more.

61914098
>>61914045
Yeah, for some reason this is considered rich when it is the buying power of a butcher in the 70s. And it’s taxed like it’s rich

61914137
>>61914098
Median income in the U.S. is around $80k a year.

RICE AND BEANS

SELL THE KIDS

61907745
>>61907724
I like what he preaches. I finally started to respect every dollar. I was in a rough spot with payday loan now that I’m out of it I started saving. He hates payday lenders so do I.

>>61905079

61908024
>>61905079

you mean your worthless papers that are spawned into existence through usury itself?

61908034
>>61905088
How much debt you in bud? Don't be mad at Dave cuz he's old school.

61908045
>>61905232
No one ever got rich from credit card perks. I'm not arguing that interest-free debt is cool but don't act like credit cards are how you get wealthy.

61908654
>>61905079
Horrible advice. Buy with credit cards that offer rewards, then pay them off in full every month before due date. Im up to 40 dols in cashback rewards just using cards instead of my debit, then paying off the bill with money I was going to use to buy the stuff in the first place. Literal free money and my credit score has been soaring. Fuck wish id done this a decade ago.

61908821
>>61905079
People meme on Dave a lot but I don't think he's that bad, I just don't think Dave is really meant for people who can control their spending. If you even somewhat understand money and you have a healthy savings account, good 401k, and don't have a ton of debt you aren't his target audience. His target audience is people who -
>are 21-50 years old
>have a $1.5k a month car loan for 84 months
>buy Labubus and other weird shit
>can't control their spending
>have 5 credit cards
>have no savings or long term investments
>make $15 an hour

61908832
>>61908654
that's the thing though, these people CANNOT control their spending. That's why giving them credit cards is a bad idea and why he says not to get them. If you know how you use a credit card IE just use it like a debit card, don't finance expensive shit or max it out, then you're fine. You gotta remember the people who need his advice probably have like sub 600 credit and ridiculous interest rates.

61908860
>>61908832
Yea. Ive come to understand as I get older peoples choices are the prime factor in their situation and bad luck is just a cope they console themselves with.

61908878
>>61908821
This anon gets it.

61909951
>>61908821
his videos have like millions of views, I wonder if theres that many people who are bad with finances

61909964
>>61905079
shit i realized when i was sixteen for 500, Alex

61909987
>>61907808

Buy platinum.

61910179
shit, my earning didn't outpace inflation. I'm now worse off than i was due to asset prices increasing before i could buy.

61911929
I’ve opened my first savings account few days ago I already have $30 saved.

I’m literally taking baby steps

61911936
>>61905079

61911940

>or women who think they should sign for loans because their boyfriend has bad credit

61912125
>>61908045

61912248
>>61909951
young people are generally very bad with money. A lot of people don't start saving until they're like 30+. I think the average savings in the US for Gen Z workers is $1000. So yes, there's a lot of people who are horrible with money. Financial classes should be a requirement in high schools.

61912706
>>61905079
>SAY NO TO MORTGAGE
I thought a mortgage was the only form of debt that he's okay with

61913103
The only chain link you need is a FENCE to keep your dumbass from walking out into the freeway. Sell it all tonight if you can.

61913157
>>61905079
what a stupid shit. in my case it is clever look at it:

>been saving for years but still can't afford expensive house
>buy cheap flat with small mortage
>i pay off small mortage and keep saving a bit for next 10 years
>sell flat, earn money because of house market appreciation
>with old flat value + savings i can now afford expensive house

if i was alergic to even small mortages i would spend 10+ years depressed in a shithole until i save enough for big house. it makes no sense

61913202

He advocates for the financial version of the keto diet, where you will lose weight but you really should’ve avoided soda (credit card debt) instead of avoiding brown rice (borrowing money to go to college and not dig ditches).

61913953

The dichotomy between NEETs and wagies is a false one
On the one hand the NEET is completely right that labor within modern institutions is conditioning the mind to slavish servitude, and that most profit of the labor is sluiced off to parasites engineering the destruction of mankind.
On the other hand, the wagie is correct that man and labor are interconnected and that man was not designed for laziness but is an inherently active and industrious creature.
The true synthesis of this false dichotomy is the self-sufficient man, the man of the land, he that owns the most primary means of survival and labors to scrape a living off of bare rocks if fate demands it, beholden to none but the physical realities resulting from his own toil
He is the Yeoman, the Free Farmer, the true synthesis of man's need to work and man's rejection of Servitude.
the Yeoman's Republic as America was meant to be, as Jefferson dreamt of; a nation of free farmers united in love for liberty and justice, and rejection of servitude in any form.

Reject the false dichotomy, acquire the land and never sell. Eat worms (eat ze bugz) if you have to, as long as they are YOUR worms on YOUR land.

"I have an extraordinarily stimulating home, family, and social life outside of work, and I try to support and bring a focused atmosphere in the office."

The clique at the office is toxic. It doesn't matter how nice and inclusive they are on the outside, the point of being in their little in-group is so they feel accepted and trusted by you, so they can strategize around what vulnerabilities they learn about you through "socialization"
It's also important to realize the clique at the office will not be composed of the most senior and productive workers. It will be largely "new" people to the corporation, who are trying to compound and roll the freshman happy-go-lucky "I made it" vibes perpetually.
Unfortunately, being a simpleton and going with the crowd at work is a way to reduce your own role, executive actions, and relevance in your life. If 20 people have to walk together and get coffee every day because.. it's what they do...they're essentially automatons, preprogrammed. If you're forced to walk at an uncomfortably brisk pace to keep up with the lead Alpha Team Member on your walks, you're being actively cucked

OP, you should be satisfied in knowing you don't fit in. You probably don't want to fit in.
